records.briefDescription: The highest-regarded guard in Vadi's system, held with the sword vertical over the lead foot.
records.fullDescription: Posta di Donna is described by its practitioner as 'the lady, without any doubt, of all the guards, and I fear none.' This versatile guard positions the sword vertically over the lead foot with a narrower stance than Fiore's version, with the point held more forward. The guard hides the sword's length from opponents while enabling powerful attacks to the opposite side. Vadi's version differs radically from Fiore dei Liberi's guard of the same name, representing a significant evolution in Italian longsword technique.
records.briefApplication: Use as a primary ready position that conceals sword length while maintaining offensive and defensive capability.
records.fullApplication: Posta di Donna serves as the cornerstone guard of Vadi's system, providing excellent versatility for both offense and defense. Its vertical sword position makes it difficult for opponents to judge distance and timing. From this guard, you can deliver powerful attacks to the opposite side with minimal telegraphing. The narrower stance compared to earlier Italian systems allows for quicker footwork transitions. Use this guard when you want to maintain a strong defensive posture while keeping offensive options open, particularly when facing uncertain opponent actions. The guard's high regard in Vadi's system makes it an essential position to master for any practitioner of his longsword method.

records.briefDescription: A high guard unique to Vadi's system with the point held aloft like a predatory bird.
records.fullDescription: Posta di Falcon represents Vadi's unique contribution to Italian longsword guards, absent from earlier systems like Fiore dei Liberi's. This high position holds the point aloft, with the practitioner resembling 'the Falcon' in their movements. The elevated sword position provides excellent leverage for both parrying incoming attacks and beating down opponent weapons. The guard's bird-of-prey imagery reflects its aggressive potential and commanding position over the combat space.
records.briefApplication: Use for beating down attacks from above and controlling the high line against opponents.
records.fullApplication: Posta di Falcon excels when you need to control the high line and threaten descending attacks. The elevated position allows you to parry incoming strikes with gravity assistance and beat down opponent guards effectively. This guard works particularly well against opponents who favor low guards or who commit to attacks that expose their upper body. The falcon imagery isn't merely poetic—like the bird striking from above, this guard enables swift, decisive descending actions. Use it when you want to establish dominance in the high line or when facing opponents with weak upper defenses. The guard's unique presence in Vadi's system suggests it addressed tactical needs he identified in his era's combat context.

records.briefDescription: A low guard positioning the sword over the lead leg with the handle near the right thigh.
records.fullDescription: Porta di Ferro Forte is one of several iron gate variations in Vadi's system. This low guard positions the sword over the lead leg with the handle resting near the right thigh and blade angled downward. The 'strong' designation indicates this version's emphasis on solid defensive positioning. Iron gate guards excel at defending against both cuts and thrusts while preparing powerful rising counterattacks. The low position invites opponents to attack high, creating opportunities for the defender to exploit.
records.briefApplication: Use to defend low while preparing rising counterattacks, especially against aggressive opponents.
records.fullApplication: Porta di Ferro Forte provides exceptional defensive coverage while baiting opponents into attacking your apparently open high lines. When opponents commit to high attacks, you can parry with rising actions that naturally flow into powerful counterstrikes. The guard's low position also protects against low attacks and thrusts to the legs while maintaining readiness to thrust upward into the opponent's face or chest. Use this guard when facing aggressive opponents who favor descending cuts, as it allows you to receive their attacks with structural advantage and immediately counter. The 'strong' nature of this variant suggests maintaining firm structure and weight commitment, making it difficult for opponents to displace your sword without significant effort.

records.briefDescription: A low iron gate variant positioned close to the ground.
records.fullDescription: Porta di Ferro Piena Terrena represents a particularly low variant of the iron gate family of guards. The term 'piena terrena' (flat ground) indicates the sword is held very close to the ground level, even lower than the standard iron gate positions. Like other iron gate guards, the sword rests over the lead leg with blade angled downward, but this version emphasizes maximum lowness. This creates an extremely defensive posture that forces opponents to commit to high attacks or risk attacking into a well-protected low line.
records.briefApplication: Use when maximum defensive coverage is needed, particularly against multiple attack angles.
records.fullApplication: Porta di Ferro Piena Terrena serves best in situations requiring maximum defensive security. The extremely low position makes it nearly impossible for opponents to attack your lower openings while forcing them to telegraph high attacks. This guard works exceptionally well when you're uncertain of opponent intentions and need time to observe and analyze their patterns. The low position also fatigues opponents less experienced with proper guard structure, as they may feel pressured to attack immediately against what appears to be a passive position. However, you must maintain readiness to respond with rising parries or thrusts, as the low position requires more movement to defend high attacks compared to middle guards. Use this when playing defensively or when you want to frustrate aggressive opponents into making hasty, exploitable attacks.

records.briefDescription: A guard with the weak leg forward, sword over the strong side with crossed wrists.
records.fullDescription: Posta di Vera Finestra holds the weak leg forward with the sword positioned over the strong side, point slightly raised, and wrists crossed in a distinctive configuration. Vadi describes this guard as 'crimson at thrusting from guard,' indicating its particular excellence for launching thrusts. The 'window' terminology suggests the opening created for thrusting attacks, while 'true' distinguishes it from false or deceptive variants. The crossed wrist position creates mechanical advantage for delivering powerful, accurate thrusts while maintaining defensive coverage.
records.briefApplication: Use primarily for delivering powerful thrusts while maintaining defensive structure.
records.fullApplication: Posta di Vera Finestra excels when thrust offense is your primary tactical goal. The crossed wrist configuration and forward weak leg create optimal biomechanics for delivering thrusts with maximum power and control. The guard's structure naturally conceals your thrust preparation while maintaining defensive coverage of your centerline. Use this guard when you've identified thrust opportunities or when facing opponents with weak thrust defense. The 'crimson' description suggests the lethal effectiveness of thrusts from this position—properly delivered, they can end exchanges decisively. The guard also works well in combination with feints, as the crossed wrist position allows quick transitions to cuts if opponents overcommit to defending thrusts. Master this guard to develop a strong thrusting game within Vadi's system.

records.briefDescription: A guard adapted from armored combat, held on the right side with threatening intent.
records.fullDescription: Posta Sagitaria adapts Fiore dei Liberi's armored sword guard to Vadi's narrower unarmored stance. Held on the right side, Vadi describes it with 'much malice in its reign,' suggesting aggressive and threatening potential. The 'archer' terminology may reference the drawn bow position or the precision and deadliness associated with archery. This guard maintains offensive threat while providing defensive coverage, embodying the principle that guards should simultaneously attack and defend.
records.briefApplication: Use for aggressive offense from the right side with deceptive and malicious intent.
records.fullApplication: Posta Sagitaria serves practitioners who favor aggressive, forward-pressure tactics. The 'much malice' description indicates this guard's primary purpose is threatening offense rather than passive defense. From this position, you can launch attacks with minimal preparation while maintaining enough defensive structure to parry incoming strikes. The archer reference suggests precision—like an archer drawing and releasing in one smooth motion, attacks from this guard should be coordinated and decisive. Use this guard when you want to pressure opponents psychologically with aggressive posture while maintaining tactical flexibility. The adaptation from armored to unarmored context shows Vadi's systematic approach to transferring principles across combat contexts. This guard works particularly well against defensive opponents who need prodding to commit to actions you can exploit.

records.briefDescription: An extended guard with the blade fully directed toward the opponent's face.
records.fullDescription: Posta Longa extends the blade fully toward the adversary with the point directed at the opponent's face. This 'long' guard emphasizes maintaining constant presence in the opponent's line of attack, making it difficult for them to initiate offense without first addressing your point. The extended nature creates maximum threat distance while maintaining defensive capability through point presence. This guard embodies Vadi's principle that 'the point should always face the opponent, especially the face,' making it a fundamental position in his system.
records.briefApplication: Use to maintain constant threat with your point while controlling the centerline.
records.fullApplication: Posta Longa serves as an excellent controlling guard that forces opponents to deal with your point before they can attack effectively. The extended position means any opponent movement toward you immediately brings them into threat range, requiring them to parry or evade your point before launching their own offense. This guard works particularly well against aggressive opponents, as it disrupts their timing and forces them to solve the problem of your threatening point. Use Posta Longa when you want to fight cautiously and force opponents to commit first, or when you need to control distance and prevent opponents from closing freely. The guard also excels in measure control—by extending and withdrawing while maintaining the point online, you can manipulate distance to your advantage. Master this guard to develop strong defensive counterattacking tactics within Vadi's framework.

records.briefDescription: A more compact guard that maintains point presence despite shorter extension.
records.fullDescription: Posta Breve maintains the point directed at the opponent's face but in a more compact configuration than Posta Longa. Despite the 'short' designation, this guard covers similar range through different body mechanics and positioning. The more compact nature allows for quicker transitions and less commitment than the long guard while maintaining the critical principle of keeping the point in the opponent's line. This guard represents Vadi's emphasis on efficiency and economy of motion.
records.briefApplication: Use when you need point threat with more mobility and quicker transition potential.
records.fullApplication: Posta Breve provides the point control of Posta Longa but with enhanced mobility and transition speed. The more compact position allows you to change guards or respond to opponent actions more quickly than from the extended long guard. Use this guard when facing unpredictable opponents or when you need to maintain defensive flexibility while keeping your point threatening. The shorter extension also reduces fatigue compared to holding full extension, making it suitable for longer exchanges. Despite covering similar range, the different mechanics mean you can surprise opponents who expect one guard by transitioning to the other. This guard works well in combination tactics—establish control with Posta Longa, then transition to Breve for quicker counterattack options. The distinction between these guards shows Vadi's sophisticated understanding of subtle positional advantages.

records.briefDescription: An aggressive low guard named after the wild boar, with point threatening toward the opponent.
records.fullDescription: Dente di Cinghiaro takes its name from the wild boar that 'lowers his face and always covers against the blows.' This aggressive low guard positions the point toward the opponent in a threatening thrust-ready stance. The boar imagery evokes the animal's dangerous nature when cornered or provoked—defensive yet capable of devastating counterattacks. Like the boar's tusks, this guard's point creates constant threat while the low position provides defensive coverage. Variants include Dente di Cinghiaro di Fora (Outside Boar's Tooth).
records.briefApplication: Use for aggressive thrust offense from a low position while maintaining defensive coverage.
records.fullApplication: Dente di Cinghiaro combines the defensive advantages of low guards with immediate thrust threat. The boar imagery is tactically instructive—like the dangerous animal, you appear defensive but can unleash sudden, devastating attacks. The point directed at the opponent creates constant psychological pressure while the low body position protects against incoming strikes. Use this guard when you want to bait opponents into attacking while maintaining a loaded thrust ready to launch. The guard works exceptionally well against opponents who favor high attacks, as you can thrust under their strikes while their weapons are committed elsewhere. The 'tooth' terminology emphasizes the piercing, penetrating nature of attacks from this position. Master this guard to develop aggressive counterattacking tactics that turn defensive positions into offensive opportunities.

records.briefDescription: A high guard held over the head in a frontal position.
records.fullDescription: Posta Frontale occupies a high position over the head, with the sword held in a frontal orientation. This guard provides excellent coverage of the high line while maintaining readiness for descending attacks. The frontal nature suggests direct, straightforward tactical application rather than deceptive or oblique approaches. This guard shares the high-line territory with Corona but emphasizes different tactical applications and body mechanics.
records.briefApplication: Use to control the high line and threaten descending attacks with direct, frontal orientation.
records.fullApplication: Posta Frontale excels when you need straightforward high-line control without the complexity of binding-focused guards like Corona. The frontal orientation makes your intentions clearer than more deceptive guards, which can be advantageous when you want opponents to respect your position and act cautiously. Use this guard when facing opponents who favor low guards or when you want to threaten descending strikes that can split through their defenses. The high position allows you to parry with gravity assistance and deliver powerful downward cuts. This guard works well in combination with footwork—maintain the frontal position while circling to create angles for your descending attacks. The straightforward nature makes it easier to teach and learn than more subtle guards, making it valuable for developing fundamental high-guard tactics.

records.briefDescription: A high crown-like guard over the head that excels at binding.
records.fullDescription: Corona holds the sword high over the head in a crown-like configuration, with its practitioner claiming 'I am master in bindings I am skilled.' This guard emphasizes binding and controlling opponent weapons rather than pure striking offense. The crown imagery suggests both the elevated position and the commanding nature of the guard—like a crown commands respect, this guard commands the high line. The guard's structure facilitates catching and controlling opponent weapons through binding actions.
records.briefApplication: Use primarily for binding opponent weapons and controlling engagements through high-line dominance.
records.fullApplication: Corona serves practitioners who excel at binding tactics and want to control opponent weapons rather than simply parry them. The high crown position allows you to catch incoming strikes and establish bindings that control subsequent actions. Use this guard when you want to dictate the flow of engagement through weapon control rather than evasive defense. The 'master in bindings' claim reflects the guard's primary purpose—from Corona, you can establish strong bindings that prevent opponents from easily disengaging while creating opportunities for thrusts, cuts, or close-play transitions. This guard requires sensitivity to pressure and timing, as successful binding depends on feeling opponent intentions through blade contact. Master Corona to develop sophisticated binding tactics that turn opponent attacks into controlled situations where you maintain advantage. The guard works particularly well against opponents who commit to attacks without proper caution.

records.briefDescription: A rear guard with the sword extended behind the body in a low position.
records.fullDescription: Coda Longa extends the sword behind the body in a low rear guard, positioned opposite to forward-facing guards like Posta Longa. The 'long tail' imagery evokes both the extended rear position and the potential for whipping attacks that can come from this loading position. This guard creates maximum chamber for powerful attacks while concealing the sword from the opponent's view. The rear position requires commitment to attack once adopted, as defensive options are limited compared to forward guards.
records.briefApplication: Use to load powerful attacks from concealment, particularly when committed to offense.
records.fullApplication: Coda Longa serves best when you're committed to launching a major offensive action. The rear extension creates maximum potential energy for cuts that sweep forward with tremendous power—like a tail whipping forward, strikes from this guard carry significant force. However, the defensive limitations mean you should adopt this guard only when you've identified a clear attacking opportunity or when you're confident in your ability to complete your offense before opponents can exploit your exposed position. Use Coda Longa when transitioning between guards to load attacks or when you want to create psychological pressure through obvious offensive preparation. The concealment factor can also work to your advantage, as opponents cannot see your blade and may misjudge distance or timing. This guard teaches the principle of committed offense—once you load, you must follow through decisively.

records.briefDescription: A vertical or diagonal descending cut with the true edge that can cleave from head to knee.
records.fullDescription: Fendente delivers vertical or diagonal descending cuts with the true edge, described as capable of cleaving 'from head to knee' and 'parting the teeth in a straight line.' This fundamental strike represents the most powerful cutting action in Vadi's system. Both Fendente Mandritto (forehand) and Fendente Roverso (backhand) exist, though Vadi notes that fendente uniquely employs the true edge regardless of direction—unlike other strikes where roverso typically indicates false edge use. This makes the fendente distinct in its mechanics and purpose.
records.briefApplication: Use for maximum cutting power in descending attacks, particularly to split opponent defenses.
records.fullApplication: Fendente represents your primary power cutting tool in Vadi's system. Use this strike when you need to cleave through opponent guards or deliver decisive finishing blows. The descending mechanics utilize gravity and full body rotation to generate maximum force. However, the power comes with commitment—fendenti take time to chamber and execute, making timing crucial. Use fendente after creating openings through feints or when opponents give you time through poor defensive positioning. The ability to deliver both mandritto and roverso fendenti with the true edge gives you options from either side while maintaining maximum cutting effectiveness. Against armored opponents, the fendente becomes primarily a setup for wrestling entries rather than a finishing strike. Master the fendente to develop powerful offense capable of overwhelming defensive guards through sheer force.

records.briefDescription: Any forehand strike from the right or strong side using the true edge.
records.fullDescription: Mandritto indicates any forehand strike delivered from the right or strong side using the true edge (filo dritto). This directional foundation of Italian swordplay encompasses all attacks that travel from the swordsman's right to left across the body. Vadi's Chapter 5 establishes the principle: 'On one side you make defence, the forehand blows go on one side.' Mandritto can describe cuts at various angles—descending, horizontal, or rising—but all share the common element of traveling from the strong side with the true edge.
records.briefApplication: Use for all offensive actions from your right side, establishing one half of your cutting vocabulary.
records.fullApplication: Mandritto forms half of your fundamental cutting vocabulary in Vadi's system. Understanding mandritto as a directional concept rather than a specific cut allows you to coordinate defense and offense—when opponents attack mandritto, you defend with specific footwork and guards, then counter appropriately. Use mandritto strikes when your sword is positioned on your right side or when tactical situations favor right-side attacks. The true edge delivery ensures maximum cutting effectiveness. Mandritto strikes can be combined—a mandritto fendente followed by mandritto volante creates combination attacks on the same side. This directional organization helps structure your tactical thinking—you don't just throw random cuts, but coordinate attacks based on which side offers the best opportunity. Master the mandritto to develop consistent offense from your strong side.

records.briefDescription: Any backhand strike from the left or weak side, typically with the false edge.
records.fullDescription: Roverso designates backhand strikes from the left or weak side, typically delivered with the false edge (filo falso). This complements the mandritto to create complete directional coverage. Vadi's Chapter 5 notes that 'the backhands attack from the other' side, establishing the systematic organization of Italian swordplay around these two fundamental directions. While most roversi employ the false edge, some variations like roverso fendente can use the true edge through particular mechanics.
records.briefApplication: Use for offensive actions from your left side, completing your cutting vocabulary with mandritto.
records.fullApplication: Roverso completes your cutting system alongside mandritto, giving you options from both sides of your body. False edge cuts often surprise opponents expecting true edge attacks, as the mechanics differ and can appear less telegraphed. Use roverso strikes when your sword is positioned on your left side or when combinations naturally flow to the weak side. The backhand mechanics of roverso cuts often generate power through different body mechanics than forehand strikes—emphasizing rotation and pull rather than push. Understanding the mandritto/roverso division helps you defend intelligently—when opponents attack roverso, specific footwork and defensive responses become optimal. Combinations alternating between mandritto and roverso keep opponents defending both sides, preventing them from settling into predictable defensive patterns. Master the roverso to develop ambidextrous offense that threatens from any position.

records.briefDescription: Horizontal or crosswise strikes that travel atraversando, from knee upward.
records.fullDescription: Volanti replace Fiore dei Liberi's term 'mezani' for horizontal or crosswise strikes. These cuts travel atraversando (crosswise), with Vadi noting 'we are volanti and we always go crosswise, from knee upwards we wound.' The flying blows can come from either side (mandritto or roverso) and target mid-level heights. They occupy a contested position in Vadi's hierarchy, with the manuscript stating they are 'often banished by fendente and punte'—suggesting their vulnerability to vertical attacks and thrusts.
records.briefApplication: Use for horizontal attacks at mid-level, particularly when targeting arms, ribs, or transitional moments.
records.fullApplication: Volanti serve best as transitional strikes or opportunistic attacks during exchanges rather than primary offensive tools. The horizontal traveling nature makes them useful for targeting extended arms and hands, cutting through mid-level openings, or connecting attacks during guard transitions. However, Vadi's warning that they're 'often banished' by fendente and thrusts means you should use them judiciously—the horizontal path makes them vulnerable to interception by vertical or thrusting actions. Use volanti when opponents overcommit to high or low guards, leaving mid-level openings. The 'flying' terminology suggests speed and lightness—these shouldn't be slow, committed cuts but rather quick, opportunistic strikes. Volanti work well in combination with other strikes, creating unpredictable attack patterns. Against experienced opponents, use volanti as setups or feints rather than finishing blows, as skilled fencers can exploit their trajectory.

records.briefDescription: Rising cuts that follow the opposite path of fendenti, traveling upward.
records.fullDescription: Rota designates Vadi's term for rising cuts, replacing Fiore's 'sottani.' These ascending strikes follow the opposite path of fendenti, traveling upward through the same planes and involving rotational body mechanics. The rota can target from knees to forehead. The manuscript presents a dialogue where 'the rota with the fendente and the volante say to the thrusts we will show that you are not so dangerous,' suggesting these cuts compete with thrusts for tactical primacy in certain situations.
records.briefApplication: Use for rising attacks, particularly when counterattacking from low guards or targeting under opponent defenses.
records.fullApplication: Rota serves as your primary rising attack tool, particularly effective when fighting from low guards like Porta di Ferro. The upward mechanics naturally counter descending attacks while threatening opponent's lower defenses. Use rota when opponents commit to high guards or descending strikes—your rising action can intercept their attack while simultaneously counterstriking. The wheel terminology reflects the rotational body mechanics required for powerful rising cuts. From low guards, the rota allows you to parry and strike in single tempo, embodying Vadi's principle of simultaneous attack and defense. Rising cuts also work well against opponent hands and arms extended for attacks. However, the upward path means you sacrifice the gravity advantage of descending cuts, so technique and timing become especially important. Master the rota to develop effective counterattacking from low positions.

records.briefDescription: A wheel-like cut delivered from the wrist with minimal chamber—first appearance in fencing literature.
records.fullDescription: Stramazzone makes its first appearance in fencing literature with Vadi's manuscript. This wheel-like cut delivered from the wrist employs rotational motion with minimal chamber. Vadi instructs: 'If you do any stramazzone, do it with little turn in front of the face.' The technique should be executed with the sword kept directly before the face, avoiding wide movements because 'any long time is lost.' This innovation prefigures later Renaissance cutting mechanics and represents one of Vadi's unique contributions to longsword technique.
records.briefApplication: Use for quick cuts with minimal preparation, particularly in close measure or when time is limited.
records.fullApplication: Stramazzone represents a significant innovation in cutting mechanics—rather than chambering through large movements, you generate power through wrist rotation while keeping the sword close to your body. This makes the cut faster and less telegraphed than traditional methods, though potentially less powerful. Use stramazzone when you need to strike quickly without time for full chambers, when fighting in closer measures where large movements are impractical, or when opponents are alert to traditional cutting preparations. The instruction to keep the sword 'in front of the face' emphasizes maintaining defensive coverage even while attacking. The stramazzone works particularly well as a follow-up to other actions or as an opportunistic strike during exchanges. Modern practitioners should study this technique carefully, as it represents early development of mechanics that become central to later Renaissance systems. Master the stramazzone to develop efficient, time-saving cutting methods.

records.briefDescription: Shortened strikes thrown during opponent's attack motion, targeting advanced body parts like hands.
records.fullDescription: Mezzo Tempo strikes occur during the opponent's attack motion, targeting advanced body parts like hands and arms as they enter measure. These shortened blows, thrown with wrist movement alone, require precise timing: 'must hit much before the attacking movement is completed.' Vadi describes half-tempo as 'the jewel of the art, because in one go it strikes and parries.' The technique represents one of Vadi's most sophisticated tactical concepts, discussed extensively in Chapter 14 and requiring mastery of both timing and distance.
records.briefApplication: Use to intercept opponent attacks by striking their advanced targets before their attack completes.
records.fullApplication: Mezzo Tempo represents the pinnacle of timing-based defense in Vadi's system. Rather than defending and then counterattacking separately, you strike incoming attacks—typically targeting the hands, arms, or weapon—simultaneously disrupting their offense while creating your own. This requires reading opponent intentions early and initiating your strike before they complete their movement. Use mezzo tempo when you recognize opponent attack preparations and can act into their tempo. The half-time nature means your strike needs less distance to travel, as you're targeting advanced body parts rather than their body core. The technique works particularly well from guards that maintain point presence like Posta Longa, as you're already threatening their line. However, mistiming means you'll be struck during your attempt, making this a high-risk, high-reward technique. Master mezzo tempo to develop sophisticated timing that transforms defense into simultaneous counteroffense.

records.briefDescription: A mysterious half-time blow to the head that simultaneously parries and wounds.
records.fullDescription: Volarica represents what Vadi calls 'the best jewel of art'—a half-time blow to the head that simultaneously parries and wounds. The manuscript describes it as breaking 'with its good edge the other's brain,' though the specific mechanics remain debated among modern practitioners. This technique exemplifies Vadi's emphasis on simultaneous attack and defense, representing the highest level of tactical sophistication where a single action achieves multiple purposes. The mysterious nature and superlative description suggest exceptional technical difficulty.
records.briefApplication: Use as the ultimate simultaneous defense and attack, though precise mechanics require careful study.
records.fullApplication: Volarica represents an aspirational technique in Vadi's system—the 'best jewel' that combines parrying and attacking in single action with devastating effectiveness. While the exact mechanics are debated, the principle is clear: a properly executed volarica defeats opponent attacks while delivering a finishing blow to their head. This likely involves timing your strike to intercept their weapon while your blade continues to their target. Use this concept to develop your understanding of simultaneous actions—rather than thinking in sequence (defend, then attack), train yourself to find actions that accomplish both goals at once. The difficulty in interpreting volarica from the manuscript reminds modern practitioners that physical demonstration was always intended to accompany written instruction. Study this technique with training partners to explore various interpretations, focusing on the principle of simultaneity rather than dogmatic adherence to any single interpretation.

records.briefDescription: Horizontal strikes at middle level targeting the body's center.
records.fullDescription: Colpi Mezani designate horizontal strikes at middle level, similar in trajectory to volanti but with distinct tactical application. These middle cuts target the body's center mass—ribs, waist, and core—with horizontal or slightly diagonal paths. The term emphasizes the target zone rather than the flying quality of volanti, suggesting more committed, finishing-type strikes rather than quick opportunistic cuts.
records.briefApplication: Use for horizontal attacks targeting the body core when you have clear openings at mid-level.
records.fullApplication: Colpi Mezani serve as finishing strikes when you've created openings at middle height. Unlike volanti which may be lighter and more opportunistic, these middle cuts aim to deliver decisive force to the body's core. Use them when opponent guards leave mid-level openings or when you've displaced their weapon sufficiently to attack the body directly. The middle level targets—ribs and waist—can be fight-ending even against armored opponents if struck with sufficient force at armor gaps. However, these committed cuts require certainty of your opening, as mistiming leaves you vulnerable to counterattacks. Coordinate middle cuts with footwork to create proper angle and distance for maximum effectiveness. Against unarmored opponents, successful middle cuts can cause immediate incapacitation through trauma or loss of breath. Master these cuts to develop finishing offense that capitalizes on created opportunities.

records.briefDescription: A forehand cut delivered with the false edge in an unorthodox direction.
records.fullDescription: Falso Dritto employs the false edge for a forehand-direction cut, creating an unorthodox attack that violates the normal mandritto/roverso edge conventions. This strike delivers false edge cuts from the strong side, typically in rising or diagonal paths that would normally use the true edge. The 'false' designation indicates both the edge used and the deceptive nature of the technique—opponents expecting true edge attacks may misjudge timing and trajectory.
records.briefApplication: Use to surprise opponents with unexpected edge and trajectory combinations from your strong side.
records.fullApplication: Falso Dritto serves primarily as a deceptive and transitional strike. The false edge delivery from forehand direction creates timing and trajectory that differs from standard mandritto, potentially bypassing opponent defenses calibrated for true edge attacks. Use this strike when opponents have adapted to your standard cutting patterns and need surprise to create openings. The false edge also allows you to strike while maintaining certain defensive positions or transitioning between guards without rechambering. However, false edge cuts generally deliver less power than true edge equivalents due to biomechanics and edge geometry, so use them for disruption, hand-sniping, or setup rather than finishing blows. The technique works particularly well in combination sequences—a false forehand followed by true edge roverso keeps opponents defending multiple angles and edges. Master false cuts to develop complete offensive vocabulary that prevents opponents from predicting your attacks.

records.briefDescription: A backhand cut with the false edge, often rising from below.
records.fullDescription: Falso Roverso delivers backhand cuts with the false edge, often in rising trajectories from low positions. While roverso normally implies false edge use, this specific designation emphasizes the false edge employment in particular tactical contexts—typically rising actions from below opponent defenses. These cuts can surprise opponents and create unpredictable attack angles while transitioning between guards or positions.
records.briefApplication: Use for deceptive rising backhand attacks that approach from unexpected angles.
records.fullApplication: Falso Roverso excels when you need to attack from low positions with your backhand side. The false edge rising cut can approach under opponent defenses while your sword transitions from low to high guards. Use this strike when fighting from Porta di Ferro or other low guards on your weak side—the false edge allows you to strike rising without fully reversing your sword position. The deceptive nature comes from the unusual combination of backhand direction and rising path with false edge, creating timing opponents may struggle to read. These cuts work well as counter-actions when opponents commit to descending attacks on your weak side. However, like all false edge cuts, expect less power than true edge equivalents, so focus on disruption and opportunity creation. Master false roverso to develop complete guard-to-guard offensive transitions from any position.

records.briefDescription: The general term for all thrusting actions, described as velenosi (venomous).
records.fullDescription: Punta encompasses all thrusting actions in Vadi's system. He describes thrusts as velenosi (venomous)—insidious and deadly weapons in the longswordsman's arsenal. The fundamental principle states that 'the point should always face the opponent, especially the face.' However, Vadi acknowledges limitations: weak parries can deflect thrusts easily, missed thrusts lose utility more than missed cuts, and thrusts become dangerous when fighting multiple opponents because they commit the sword forward.
records.briefApplication: Use thrusts for precise, deadly attacks, particularly to the face, while maintaining point presence.
records.fullApplication: Punta represents your most precise and potentially lethal offensive tool. Thrusts require less movement than cuts and can strike with deadly accuracy to small targets like the face and throat. The 'venomous' description reflects their insidious nature—a successful thrust often ends the fight immediately, while the threat of thrust forces opponents to maintain defensive awareness. Use thrusts when you've established point presence in opponent's line, when attacking through small openings, or when you need attacks that commit less movement than cuts. Maintain your point directed at opponent's face as Vadi instructs, forcing them to constantly address this threat. However, understand the limitations—if opponents parry your thrust, you're often more compromised than after a parried cut. Against multiple opponents, the forward commitment of thrusts becomes dangerous, making cuts more appropriate. Master the thrust to develop precise, efficient offense that threatens from any position maintaining point presence.

records.briefDescription: A thrust delivered with knuckles up in pronation.
records.fullDescription: Punta Sopramano delivers the point with knuckles up and hand in pronation. This overhand configuration represents the more natural thrusting position for many guards and provides structural strength through arm alignment. However, Vadi shows preference for the underhand thrust, describing the overhand as less sophisticated than its counterpart. The overhand thrust works well from high guards and provides power through skeletal alignment.
records.briefApplication: Use for powerful, structurally sound thrusts from high positions.
records.fullApplication: Punta Sopramano serves best when thrusting from high guards or when you need maximum structural strength in your thrust. The pronated hand position creates strong skeletal alignment that can push through weak parries or maintain pressure in bindings. Use this thrust when you need power over deception, when fighting from guards like Posta di Donna or Corona, or when opponent defenses require forcing rather than finessing. The overhand position also allows you to maintain certain defensive structures while thrusting. However, Vadi's preference for underhand thrusts suggests you should develop both but favor the more 'fencing-like' underhand variant when possible. The overhand thrust works well in combination with descending cuts, as the hand position remains similar between thrust and fendente. Master both thrust variants to maintain tactical flexibility across different guards and situations.

records.briefDescription: A thrust delivered with palm up in supination—Vadi's preferred method.
records.fullDescription: Punta Sottomano extends the point with palm up in supination. Vadi explicitly favors this underhand thrust as 'more insidious and fencing-like' than the overhand variant, reflecting his emphasis on deceptive, technically sophisticated actions over raw power. The supinated hand position creates different mechanics that can be harder for opponents to read and allows for particular guard transitions and defensive combinations.
records.briefApplication: Use as your primary thrust—more deceptive and technically sophisticated than overhand.
records.fullApplication: Punta Sottomano represents Vadi's preferred thrusting method, embodying his emphasis on technical sophistication over raw power. The supinated hand position makes the thrust more difficult for opponents to read in preparation, as the mechanics differ from the more common overhand variant. Use this thrust as your primary thrusting action, particularly when you want deception and inscrutability in your offense. The underhand position works exceptionally well from guards like Posta di Vera Finestra and lower positions, allowing you to maintain defensive structure while preparing the thrust. The 'insidious' nature means opponents may not recognize your thrust preparation until it's too late to defend effectively. The supinated position also facilitates certain guard transitions and allows you to thrust while maintaining crossed-hand defensive structures. Master the underhand thrust to align with Vadi's technical philosophy of sophistication over strength.

records.briefDescription: Feinting thrusts or deceptive point actions to mislead opponents.
records.fullDescription: Punta Falsa indicates feinting thrusts or thrusts delivered deceptively to mislead opponents about true intent. These false actions create opportunities by causing opponent reactions to non-committal or misdirected threats. The false thrust embodies Vadi's emphasis on ingegno (cleverness) over force, using deception to create openings rather than forcing through opponent defenses.
records.briefApplication: Use to create openings through deceptive threat, causing opponents to react to false attacks.
records.fullApplication: Punta Falsa serves as a primary tool for creating opportunities through deception. Rather than committing fully to a thrust, you show intention toward one target, causing opponent defensive reactions, then exploit the openings their reactions create. Use false thrusts when opponents defend your point presence too eagerly—their overreaction to a false threat leaves them vulnerable to your real attack. The technique requires restraint—you must show enough threat to provoke reaction without committing so far you cannot recover for your real action. False thrusts work particularly well in combination: false thrust high, then thrust or cut low to the opening created. Against experienced opponents, layering multiple levels of false action can be necessary, as they won't react to simple feints. Master the false thrust to develop sophisticated offense based on ingegno rather than raw aggression. This technique exemplifies Vadi's philosophical emphasis on cleverness over strength.

records.briefDescription: Vadi's innovative footwork involving knee flexion with extended rear leg—his claimed unique contribution.
records.fullDescription: Passeggiar represents Vadi's claimed innovation in longsword mechanics. This distinctive footwork involves flexing the knee of the advanced leg while extending the rear leg, creating a lunge-like position shorter than modern Olympic fencing but longer than Fiore's compact steps. Vadi emphasizes this departure from earlier Italian tradition as his unique contribution, stating it creates more efficient, compact movement than previous methods.
records.briefApplication: Use as your primary footwork method for attacks—more efficient than passing steps.
records.fullApplication: Passeggiar forms the foundation of Vadi's movement system, representing his signature contribution to Italian longsword technique. Rather than taking full passing steps for every attack, you extend forward by flexing your lead knee and straightening your rear leg, creating a longer stance that delivers power while maintaining balance and recovery potential. Use this footwork for all attacks and aggressive movements—Vadi explicitly advocates 'attacking with acressimento rather than the pass,' suggesting passeggiar as the primary attacking motion. The extended rear leg provides stability and power generation while the flexed front leg maintains readiness to recover or advance further. This creates the narrower, more compact movement style that characterizes Vadi's system compared to predecessors. Practice passeggiar extensively to internalize Vadi's movement philosophy. The technique requires leg strength and flexibility but rewards practitioners with efficient, powerful attacks that don't overcommit.

records.briefDescription: A full step where the rear foot comes forward past the lead foot.
records.fullDescription: Passare describes a full step where the rear foot comes forward past the lead foot, like normal walking. This represents complete weight transfer and stance reversal, used to cover significant distance or change stance orientation. However, Vadi de-emphasizes passing in favor of his acressimento (advancing) footwork, suggesting passing should be used selectively rather than as the primary attacking footwork.
records.briefApplication: Use for covering significant distance or changing stance, but prefer acressimento for attacks.
records.fullApplication: Passare serves specific tactical needs in Vadi's system, though it's not the primary attacking footwork. Use passing steps when you need to cover distance greater than acressimento allows, when changing stance orientation (switching lead legs), when transitioning between widely separated positions, or when pursuing retreating opponents. The full step commits more than passeggiar, making it appropriate when you're certain of your action. However, Vadi's de-emphasis suggests you should default to acressimento for most attacks, reserving passing for special circumstances. Passing steps can also be tactical—sometimes taking a full step creates the distance change needed to exploit opponent timing. In combinations, alternating passing with acressimento creates varied rhythms that prevent opponents from timing your attacks. Master passing as part of your complete footwork vocabulary, but remember Vadi's preference for more compact, efficient acressimento in typical attacking situations.

records.briefDescription: Moving the lead foot forward while the back foot follows, maintaining stance relationship.
records.fullDescription: Acressimento or Accrescere (Increasing/Advancing) moves the lead foot forward while the back foot follows, maintaining the same stance relationship. Vadi explicitly advocates 'attacking with acressimento rather than the pass,' promoting narrower stances and smaller, faster cuts than predecessors. This advancing footwork enables the compact, efficient movement that characterizes Vadi's system and coordinates perfectly with his passeggiar mechanics.
records.briefApplication: Use as your primary advancing footwork, maintaining stance while closing distance.
records.fullApplication: Acressimento represents Vadi's preferred method for advancing and attacking, emphasizing efficiency over large movements. Rather than taking full passing steps that reverse your stance, you advance by moving your lead foot forward and bringing your rear foot up, maintaining your stance orientation. This creates smooth, controlled advances that keep you balanced and ready to attack or defend at any moment. Use acressimento for all standard attacks and pressure applications—the maintained stance means you're always in proper position. The incremental nature allows you to modulate distance precisely, advancing just enough to reach targets without overcommitting. Combined with passeggiar (the extended rear leg position), acressimento creates the characteristic Vadi stance and movement style. Practice advancing with acressimento while maintaining proper guard structure—your sword should move with your body, not separately. Master this footwork to develop the compact, efficient movement Vadi advocates throughout his manuscript.

records.briefDescription: Stepping backward to increase distance or evade attacks.
records.fullDescription: Tornare indicates stepping backward, essentially the reverse of advancing footwork. This defensive movement increases distance from opponents, evades attacks, or creates space for counterattacks. The term literally means 'return,' suggesting movement back to previous positions or away from engaged measure. Retreating footwork requires discipline to avoid becoming purely reactive.
records.briefApplication: Use to evade attacks and create distance, but maintain offensive capability while retreating.
records.fullApplication: Tornare serves critical defensive purposes but must be used with tactical awareness. Retreat to evade attacks you cannot parry safely, to draw opponents into overextending, to create distance for thrust actions, or to reset exchanges when disadvantaged. However, pure retreat without offensive intent allows opponents to control the engagement. Use tornare actively—retreat while maintaining your point online, threatening thrusts as opponents advance, or retreat to specific positions that offer tactical advantage. The 'return' terminology suggests purposeful retreat to positions you control rather than panicked flight. In combinations, retreating followed by sudden advance (tornare then acressimento) can catch opponents overcommitting to their pursuit. Practice retreating while maintaining proper guards and point presence—your sword should continue threatening even as you withdraw. Master tornare to develop complete tactical mobility that includes knowing when to give ground strategically.

records.briefDescription: Crossing steps and lateral movements to change angle.
records.fullDescription: Traversare designates crossing steps and lateral movements that change your angle relative to opponents without simply advancing or retreating. These sideways movements create new angles for attack and defense while maintaining or adjusting distance. Crossing steps can also refer to the physical act of one foot crossing past the other during certain movements.
records.briefApplication: Use to create angles and flanking positions rather than simply advancing or retreating.
records.fullApplication: Traversare provides the angular dimension of footwork, allowing you to circumvent opponent defenses rather than just pushing forward or backing away. Use lateral movements to circle around opponent strong positions, to create angles that expose their flanks, to evade linear attacks while maintaining offensive position, or to break out of unfavorable engagements. Crossing steps allow you to change position quickly while maintaining or closing distance. These movements work particularly well combined with attacks—traverse to create an angle, then strike to the opening your movement revealed. Against opponents who favor forward pressure, lateral movement can frustrate their tactics by removing the straight-line target they expect. Practice traversing in multiple directions, maintaining proper guard structure throughout the movement. Master traversare to develop three-dimensional footwork that doesn't just advance and retreat but commands the full fighting space.

records.briefDescription: Rotational footwork and body turning movements.
records.fullDescription: Voltare encompasses rotational footwork and turning movements that change your facing and body orientation. These turns can range from small adjustments to complete about-faces, serving both offensive and defensive purposes. Turning movements appear in Vadi's system as tactical responses to opponent actions and as methods for generating power in strikes through body rotation.
records.briefApplication: Use to change facing, evade attacks, or generate rotational power in strikes.
records.fullApplication: Voltare serves multiple tactical purposes depending on the degree and context of turning. Small turns adjust your facing to track opponent movement or optimize striking angles. Larger turns (mezza volta or tutta volta) change your orientation significantly, useful for evading attacks, resetting position, or dealing with multiple opponents. Turning also generates power—many cuts rely on body rotation coordinated with arm movement. Use turning defensively to remove your body from attack lines while maintaining weapon control, or offensively to add rotational power to strikes. The instruction to 'face the side to which you turn, and enter there' suggests turns should be purposeful, moving you toward tactical advantage rather than away from opponents. Practice turning while maintaining guards and point control—your weapon should move with your body rotation in coordinated fashion. Master voltare to develop fluid transitions between positions and the ability to respond to attacks from any angle.

records.briefDescription: A 90-degree rotation to change facing direction.
records.fullDescription: Mezza Volta executes a 90-degree rotation, changing your facing by a quarter circle. This moderate turn allows you to address opponents approaching from the side, to evade linear attacks while maintaining offensive position, or to transition between different tactical orientations. The half turn represents a common tactical adjustment in dynamic combat situations.
records.briefApplication: Use to address flanking opponents or evade attacks while maintaining offensive capability.
records.fullApplication: Mezza Volta provides the tactical flexibility to address threats from multiple angles without completely disengaging. Use the half turn when opponents circle to your flank—rather than pursuing them with footwork, turn to face them directly, maintaining optimal striking position. The 90-degree rotation also works defensively against linear attacks: as opponents commit forward, turn perpendicular to their line, evading while positioning for counterattacks to their now-exposed flank. In multiple opponent situations, half turns allow you to keep threats within your field of vision and striking range. The moderate degree means you maintain reasonable position relative to your original opponent while addressing new threats. Practice mezza volta in combination with strikes—turn and strike simultaneously to create powerful, unexpected attacks. The rotation can also add force to certain cuts through centrifugal effect. Master the half turn to develop tactical flexibility in complex fighting situations.

records.briefDescription: A 180-degree about-face rotation.
records.fullDescription: Tutta Volta completes a 180-degree about-face, reversing your facing direction completely. This full turn represents significant tactical repositioning, used to address threats from behind, to evade attacks by moving through larger angles, or to completely reset engagement orientation. The whole turn commits more than smaller rotations but provides maximum angular change.
records.briefApplication: Use to address rear threats or completely reset engagement orientation.
records.fullApplication: Tutta Volta serves situations requiring complete orientation reversal. Use the full turn when threats approach from behind—rather than awkward backward defense, complete the turn to face them properly. The 180-degree rotation also works as an extreme evasion: when opponents commit to powerful forward attacks, turning through the full rotation moves you far from their attack line while potentially positioning you at their flank or rear. In multiple opponent contexts, full turns become necessary to manage threats from all directions. However, the large angular change means momentary vulnerability during the turn, so time it carefully. Some techniques deliberately turn away from opponents as setup for follow-up actions—the apparent retreat draws them forward into counterattacks. Practice tutta volta maintaining weapon control throughout—your sword should provide protection even mid-turn. Master the whole turn to develop complete spatial mobility that can address threats from any direction.

records.briefDescription: The distance between fencers, which changes tactical options and tempo.
records.fullDescription: Misura describes the distance between fencers, which changes tactical options and available tempo. Vadi instructs practitioners to 'measure blows and steps together,' coordinating distance with action. Measure is not fixed or absolute but depends on the relative size and reach of both combatants. Chapter 3 establishes the principle: 'With your eye on the weapon that can attack you, seize both the tempo and the measure together,' insisting that timing and distance must be coordinated.
records.briefApplication: Maintain constant awareness of distance and coordinate all actions with proper measure.
records.fullApplication: Misura represents one half of Vadi's fundamental tactical framework (alongside tempo). You must constantly assess and adjust distance relative to opponents, understanding that different measures enable different actions. Too far, and your attacks cannot reach; too close, and you cannot use your weapon effectively. Proper measure means positioning where your attacks reach opponents while theirs fall short, or where you can defend effectively against their attacks. Use footwork to manipulate measure—advance to bring opponents into range, retreat to make their attacks fall short, or maintain measure to control engagement flow. The instruction to 'measure blows and steps together' means every attack must coordinate distance covered with weapon movement—don't swing at air or stop short of targets. Different opponents require different measures based on their size and weapon reach. Master measure awareness to develop precise distance control that enables your offense while frustrating opponent attacks.

records.briefDescription: Long to medium distance where practitioners focus on cuts and thrusts with the last third of blade.
records.fullDescription: Giocco Largo encompasses long to medium distance where practitioners focus on cuts and thrusts with the last third of the blade. No body-to-body contact or grips occur here, though the range can include kicks and sword grips. This is where fights begin and develop. The wide play represents the majority of longsword combat, where proper technique with the weapon's striking portion determines success.
records.briefApplication: Use as the primary combat distance for most longsword exchanges with cuts and thrusts.
records.fullApplication: Giocco Largo represents your primary tactical environment in longsword combat. At this distance, you use the sword as it's designed—cutting and thrusting with the last third of the blade where leverage and speed optimize effectiveness. Most exchanges begin and remain in wide play, making it essential to master. Use cuts and thrusts appropriate to the distance, maintaining proper guards, and controlling measure to keep opponents in your optimal range while staying outside theirs. Wide play emphasizes weapon technique over wrestling—your success depends on proper cutting mechanics, thrust precision, and guard transitions. However, always remain aware that exchanges can transition to closer play, requiring adaptation. The distance allows both defense and offense: you have space to parry and counter, time to read opponent intentions, and room to maneuver. Master giocco largo to develop fundamental longsword skills that form the basis of Vadi's system.

records.briefDescription: The critical transitional distance where swords cross in the middle—bridge between largo and stretto.
records.fullDescription: Mezza Spada represents the critical transitional distance where swords cross in the middle when both strike. This 'bridge between largo and stretto' constitutes the most important part of wide play. As Chapter 3 states: 'When he comes to the half sword, I begin my play.' At this distance, techniques from both wide and close play become available. The term also indicates the gripping technique of holding the sword blade with the left hand for close combat leverage.
records.briefApplication: Recognize this critical distance where both wide and close techniques become available—the true battleground.
records.fullApplication: Mezza Spada represents the most tactically complex distance in Vadi's system because both wide play and close play techniques become viable options. When swords cross at their middles, you face critical decisions: maintain distance and use cutting/thrusting, or close to grappling range and use wrestling techniques. This is 'where I begin my play' because both combatants must make tactical choices that determine how the exchange develops. Use this distance to control engagement flow—if you want to keep fighting with the sword, maintain mezza spada without closing; if you want to wrestle, use it as a launching point for entries to stretto. The crossing at this distance also creates binding opportunities where you can control opponent weapons. As a gripping technique, mezza spada (left hand on blade) provides leverage and control for thrusting into armor gaps or for wrestling actions. Master this distance to develop tactical sophistication in choosing when to maintain weapon range versus closing to grappling.

records.briefDescription: Grappling distance where grips, disarms, throws, and body contact dominate.
records.fullDescription: Giocco Stretto brings combatants to grappling distance where grips, disarms, throws, and body contact dominate. At this range, practitioners can reach opponents with an extended arm, and the point is 'not divided at all' from the companion. Wrestling techniques and joint locks become primary tools. The sword becomes a lever for grappling rather than primarily a cutting weapon, with pommel strikes, crossguard hooks, and blade grips taking precedence.
records.briefApplication: Use wrestling techniques, grips, and close-range sword applications when at body-to-body range.
records.fullApplication: Giocco Stretto represents a fundamental shift in tactical approach—the sword becomes a tool for grappling rather than primarily for cutting. At this range, successful technique depends more on wrestling skill, leverage, and body mechanics than on proper cutting form. Use close play when exchanges naturally progress to this range, when you've successfully closed distance against opponents, or when fighting armored opponents where thrusting to gaps and wrestling are more effective than cutting. Techniques at this distance include arm locks, throws, disarms, pommel strikes to the head, crossguard hooks to trap limbs, and mezza spada (half-sword grip) for leverage. However, closing to stretto is risky—if your entry fails, you may be at disadvantage. The 'point not divided' description emphasizes the intimate, dangerous nature of this range. Master giocco stretto to become a complete fighter capable at all distances, not just at sword range.

records.briefDescription: The opportune moment to strike, timing of actions, and rhythm of combat.
records.fullDescription: Tempo carries multiple meanings in Vadi's system: the opportune moment to strike, a complete action or movement, and the overall timing or rhythm of combat. Chapter 10 advises: 'Seize the opportunity (tempo) so that it does not cost you dearly,' while Chapter 13 instructs: 'Then use your strikes in the correct tempo.' Chapter 3 establishes: 'With your eye on the weapon that can attack you, seize both the tempo and the measure together,' linking timing inseparably with distance.
records.briefApplication: Maintain constant awareness of timing—when to act, how long actions take, and combat rhythm.
records.fullApplication: Tempo represents the temporal dimension of combat, as critical as measure (distance) to success. You must recognize opportune moments to strike—when opponents are vulnerable, when their weapons are displaced, when they transition between guards. Every action has tempo: some techniques take largo tempo (long time), others mezzo tempo (half-time). Understanding action tempo helps you choose appropriate techniques for available time. The combat rhythm aspect means recognizing patterns in exchanges—if opponents attack in predictable tempo, you can counter-time them. Vadi's insistence on seizing tempo and measure together means you cannot successfully attack with good distance but wrong timing, nor good timing with wrong distance. Both must align. Use feints and false actions to disrupt opponent tempo, making them react at wrong times. Master tempo awareness to develop timing that exploits opponent vulnerability while avoiding their tempo traps.

records.briefDescription: The cunning and cleverness that overcomes strength—core principle of Vadi's philosophy.
records.fullDescription: Ingegno (Cleverness/Ingenuity) appears in Vadi's Latin maxim 'Ingenium superat vires' (Cleverness overcomes strength). Vadi insists that 'Ingegno ogni possanza sforza' (Cunning wins any strength), prioritizing technical sophistication over raw power. This core principle argues that intelligent application of technique, deception, and tactical awareness defeats pure physical strength and aggression.
records.briefApplication: Prioritize clever technique and deception over raw strength in all combat applications.
records.fullApplication: Ingegno represents Vadi's central philosophical principle—successful fencing depends more on cleverness than strength. Rather than trying to overpower opponents, use technique, timing, deception, and tactical awareness to create situations where their strength becomes irrelevant. This manifests in multiple ways: use feints to create openings rather than forcing through guards; use proper mechanics to generate power efficiently rather than muscling attacks; use timing to strike opponents during their vulnerable moments rather than engaging in strength contests. The principle also suggests studying opponents to identify weaknesses you can exploit through cleverness. Against stronger opponents, ingegno becomes essential—you cannot match their power, so you must exceed their tactical awareness. Even against weaker opponents, relying on strength rather than technique develops bad habits. Master the principle of ingegno to become a complete fighter whose success depends on skill and intelligence rather than physical gifts that may fade with age.

records.briefDescription: Active defense that flows from guard to guard with movement rather than static blocking.
records.fullDescription: Parare (Parrying) represents active defense rather than static blocking. Vadi instructs: 'Parries with a fendente so you are not caught,' suggesting defense should flow into counterattacks. Defense flows from guard to guard, with each position naturally transitioning into others as opponents attack. Successful parrying doesn't just stop attacks but creates opportunities for counteroffense.
records.briefApplication: Use active parries that flow into counterattacks rather than stopping movement.
records.fullApplication: Parare in Vadi's system emphasizes active, flowing defense rather than passive blocking. When opponents attack, don't simply stop their weapon—parry while moving into position for immediate counterattack. The instruction to 'parry with a fendente' means your defensive movement should be the beginning of your counteroffensive strike. This creates single-tempo defense where parrying and counterstriking occur in one flowing action. Use footwork with parries—don't stand still and block, but move offline while deflecting. Each guard has natural parrying strengths based on its structure, so parrying often means transitioning from your current guard to one that deflects the incoming attack while positioning for your counter. The flowing nature means you're never static—defense becomes part of continuous guard-to-guard movement. Master active parrying to eliminate the tempo loss of separate defensive and offensive actions, embodying Vadi's principle of simultaneity.

records.briefDescription: Creating an X or cross with the swords, the fundamental defensive action.
records.fullDescription: Incrosar or Incrossare (Crossing) forms the fundamental defensive action, creating an X or cross with the swords. Three types exist based on blade contact position: crossing at punta di spada (the point/weak), mezza spada (the middle), or tutta spada (the forte/strong). These crossing distinctions determine tactical responses and available techniques. La Croce (The Cross) represents both the cross-parry and cross guard positions.
records.briefApplication: Use sword crossings to defend while establishing control of opponent weapons.
records.fullApplication: Incrosar represents the fundamental mechanism of blade defense in Vadi's system. Rather than avoiding opponent weapons entirely, you cross your sword with theirs, creating the X formation that gives you leverage to redirect their force. The crossing position matters critically: crossing at the weak (point) gives you leverage advantage but requires precise timing; crossing at middle creates roughly equal leverage; crossing at your strong against their weak gives maximum control. Use crossings not just to deflect attacks but to establish control that prevents opponents from easily disengaging for follow-up attacks. From crossed positions, you can thrust, cut to openings, or transition to wrestling. One play advises: 'Play with the cross and you will not be conquered,' suggesting the crossing formation's fundamental importance. Practice feeling pressure through crossings to develop sensitivity that tells you when opponents are strong or weak in the bind. Master incrosar to develop sophisticated blade work that controls opponent weapons rather than just avoiding them.

records.briefDescription: Maintaining pressure and contact with opponent's blade to control their weapon.
records.fullDescription: Ligare (Binding) describes maintaining pressure and contact with the opponent's blade. Blade pressure management becomes critical in bindings and crossings, with Corona claiming: 'In bindings I am skilled.' Winning or losing the bind determines follow-up actions—whether you can thrust, cut, or must defend. Bindings create situations where both weapons are engaged, requiring sensitivity to pressure to determine tactical advantage.
records.briefApplication: Use bindings to maintain contact and control opponent weapons through pressure management.
records.fullApplication: Ligare represents sophisticated blade control that goes beyond momentary parrying to sustained weapon contact. When you bind opponent weapons, you maintain pressure that prevents them from easily disengaging while you assess opportunities. Winning the bind means establishing superior leverage or pressure that controls their weapon despite their efforts to free it. Use bindings to create opportunities: from a won bind, you can thrust to openings while their weapon is controlled, cut to targets they cannot defend, or transition to wrestling. Losing the bind means opponents have gained control, requiring you to defend rather than attack. Develop pressure sensitivity through practice—you must feel through the sword whether opponents are strong or weak in the bind, whether they're pressing or releasing, whether they're preparing actions. Corona's claim to be 'master in bindings' suggests this guard's particular excellence at these techniques. Master ligare to develop binding skills that control engagements through sustained weapon contact.

records.briefDescription: Deceptive actions used to mislead opponents about true attack intentions.
records.fullDescription: Viste (Feints) receive dedicated treatment in Chapter 12: 'Ragion de' viste de spada' (Discourse of Feints). 'Feints are used to deceive the opponent, not letting him understand to which part you want to throw your real attack.' Vadi insists feints 'must be quick and short' and practitioners should 'never bring the sword too far from the line, in order to be able to call it back to the defence without delay.' The verb form Visteggi (Feinting) appears uniquely in Vadi's manuscript.
records.briefApplication: Use quick, short feints to create openings while maintaining defensive capability.
records.fullApplication: Viste represent sophisticated offensive tactics based on deception rather than force. Rather than attacking directly, show intention toward one target, causing opponent defensive reactions that create openings elsewhere. Use feints when opponents defend too eagerly—their reactions to false threats leave them vulnerable to real attacks. Vadi's instruction that feints must be 'quick and short' means they should appear genuine enough to provoke reactions but commit little enough that you can immediately shift to your real action. The warning never to bring the sword 'too far from the line' emphasizes maintaining defensive coverage even during feinting—if opponents don't react to your feint but instead counterattack, you must be able to defend. Layer feints: false thrust high provokes high defense, then cut low; false cut right provokes right defense, then thrust center. Against experienced opponents, multiple levels of feinting may be necessary. Master viste to develop offense based on ingegno that creates openings through cleverness rather than forcing through superior strength or speed.

records.briefDescription: Broader tactical misdirection beyond simple feints.
records.fullDescription: Inganno (Deception/Trick) encompasses broader tactical misdirection beyond simple feints. This includes false guards, deceptive movements, tactical misdirection, and psychological manipulation. While viste focuses specifically on false attacks, inganno represents the full spectrum of deceptive tactics available to clever fencers.
records.briefApplication: Use all forms of deception to mislead opponents about your true capabilities and intentions.
records.fullApplication: Inganno represents comprehensive deception extending beyond just feinting attacks. Use false guards that appear vulnerable but are actually traps; show apparent weaknesses that bait opponent attacks into your prepared counters; pretend fatigue or incompetence to encourage opponent overconfidence; use rhythm changes to disrupt opponent timing expectations. Deception can be strategic—hiding your true skill level until critical moments—or tactical—misleading about immediate intentions. Against skilled opponents, layered deception becomes necessary: they won't fall for simple tricks, so you must deceive about your deceptions. However, Vadi's emphasis on prudenza (prudence) suggests deception should be calculated rather than reckless. Failed deceptions can leave you vulnerable, so maintain defensive awareness even during deceptive actions. The principle of ingegno over force suggests that mastering inganno makes you dangerous even against stronger, faster opponents. Master comprehensive deception to develop tactical sophistication that controls opponent perceptions and reactions.

records.briefDescription: The theoretical and systematic framework governing fencing practice.
records.fullDescription: Ragione (Reason/Theory/Discourse) appears throughout chapter titles: 'Ragion de spada' (Discourse of the Sword), 'Ragion de gioco' (Discourse of Play), 'Ragion de' viste de spada' (Discourse of Feints). This systematic approach to organizing knowledge represents unprecedented detail in 15th-century fencing literature. Ragione embodies the theoretical framework that governs practical application, reflecting Vadi's assertion that fencing is a science born from geometry.
records.briefApplication: Study the theoretical principles underlying techniques to understand why they work, not just how.
records.fullApplication: Ragione represents Vadi's systematic, theoretical approach to martial arts, distinguishing his work from purely practical manuals. Rather than just showing techniques, he provides theoretical frameworks explaining why they work. Use this approach in your own study: don't just memorize techniques, understand the principles governing their success. When you understand ragione—the geometric, biomechanical, and tactical principles—you can adapt techniques to new situations and even create new techniques that align with proven principles. Vadi's emphasis on ragione reflects Renaissance intellectual culture that valued systematic knowledge organization. The various 'ragion' chapter titles show his attempt to comprehensively explain different aspects of swordsmanship through reasoned discourse. Study theory alongside practice to develop deeper understanding that elevates you beyond mere technique collection to genuine systematic comprehension. This theoretical foundation allows you to teach effectively and troubleshoot problems in your own performance.

records.briefDescription: The mathematical foundation from which fencing is born according to Vadi's philosophy.
records.fullDescription: Geometria (Geometry) provides the foundational structure: 'Geometry, which divides and separates, by infinite numbers and measures and fills her papers with science.' The relationship extends universally: 'From Geometry fencing is born, and under her it has no end.' Both geometry and fencing are infinite in nature—'In fencing there is no end, as every reverse finds his right, contrary by contrary without an end.' This mathematical foundation distinguishes Vadi's intellectual approach.
records.briefApplication: Understand fencing as applied geometry—angles, distances, and spatial relationships govern success.
