records.fullApplication: Geometria represents Vadi's core philosophical claim that fencing constitutes a science based on mathematical principles rather than just an art learned through imitation. Every aspect of fencing has geometric foundations: measure is geometric distance; angles of attack and defense follow geometric principles; leverage in bindings obeys geometric laws; proper body mechanics align with geometric efficiency. Use this perspective to analyze techniques: why does this angle of attack work? How does this leverage create advantage? What geometric principles make this guard effective? Understanding the geometric foundations allows you to optimize technique beyond traditional forms. The 'infinite' nature suggests endless variation within geometric principles—you can never exhaust the possibilities because geometric principles allow infinite application. Modern practitioners should study actual geometry alongside fencing to understand Vadi's vision of martial arts as applied mathematics. This elevates fencing from mere brawling to intellectual pursuit worthy of educated nobility.

records.briefDescription: The temporal and rhythmic framework governing timing and tempo.
records.fullDescription: Musica (Music) adds the temporal dimension: 'Music adorns her and chooses her as its subject, song and sound are added to the art, to make it a more perfect science.' The manuscript explains: 'So geometry and Music combine their scientific virtues in the sword, to adorn the great light of Mars.' Music provides the rhythmic framework governing tempo, while geometry provides spatial structure governing measure.
records.briefApplication: Understand combat timing and rhythm as musical—tempo, rhythm, and pacing govern engagement flow.
records.fullApplication: Musica represents the temporal complement to geometry's spatial dimension. Just as geometry governs measure (distance), music governs tempo (timing). Combat has rhythm: attacks come in patterns, defenses follow cadence, exchanges have flow. Understanding musical principles helps you develop timing awareness. Like music, combat has meter—regular patterns of strong and weak beats. Recognizing opponent rhythm allows you to syncopate against it, acting in their weak beats. Combat also has dynamics—loud and soft, aggressive and defensive passages. Use musical thinking to develop tactical sophistication: establish a rhythm, then break it to surprise opponents; maintain steady tempo to control engagement pace; accelerate or decelerate to disrupt opponent timing. The combination of geometry (space) and music (time) creates complete combat understanding. Modern practitioners might study actual music to develop rhythmic awareness applicable to fencing. This philosophical framework elevates fencing to an art form combining mathematics and aesthetics.

records.briefDescription: Practical skill taught through apprenticeship—embodied, human-centered martial activity.
records.fullDescription: Arte (Art) represents practical skill taught by apprenticeship or rote copying of a master—embodied, human-centered activity dealing with combat's chaos and unpredictability. In Vadi's framework, art deals with the practical, physical execution of techniques, the craft learned through repetition and correction, and the embodied knowledge that cannot be fully captured in words or theory.
records.briefApplication: Develop practical skill through repetition, physical practice, and embodied learning under guidance.
records.fullApplication: Arte represents the practical dimension of martial arts—the physical skills that must be learned through doing rather than just understanding theoretically. While Vadi argues fencing is ultimately a science, he acknowledges the arte component: physical execution requires practice, body knowledge develops through repetition, and skilled performance emerges from apprenticeship under masters. Use this understanding to balance your training: theory (scientia) provides framework and principles, but art (arte) requires physical practice. You cannot learn fencing purely intellectually—you must develop embodied skills through drilling, sparring, and correction from experienced practitioners. Arte also encompasses the craft aspects: developing proper cutting mechanics, building muscle memory for guard transitions, training reflexes for defensive responses. The tension between arte and scientia in Vadi's work reflects his sophisticated understanding that both matter. Don't just study theory and neglect practice, but also don't just practice without understanding the governing principles.

records.briefDescription: Certain, absolute knowledge derived from first principles—fencing's theoretical foundation.
records.fullDescription: Scientia (Science) represents certain, absolute knowledge derived from first principles, providing the theoretical framework governing practice. Vadi argues in Chapter 1: 'If you wish to truly know if fencing is an art or science hark my words, I say. Ponder this, my statement: it is a true science and not an art.' Science provides systematic understanding of why techniques work, deriving practical application from geometric and musical principles.
records.briefApplication: Study systematic principles and theoretical frameworks to understand the science underlying practical techniques.
records.fullApplication: Scientia represents Vadi's claim that fencing constitutes systematic, theoretical knowledge derived from mathematical principles rather than just craft learned through imitation. This scientific approach means understanding why techniques work, not just how to perform them. Use scientia to elevate your understanding: when you learn a technique, study the underlying principles—what geometric advantages does it create? What timing principles does it exploit? How does it align with biomechanical efficiency? Scientific understanding allows you to adapt techniques to new situations because you understand governing principles rather than just memorized forms. Vadi's assertion of fencing as science rather than art was ambitious for his era, claiming intellectual status for martial pursuits. Modern practitioners should embrace this scientific approach: test techniques systematically, analyze successes and failures to understand principles, and organize knowledge into coherent frameworks. However, remember Vadi's ultimate resolution: fencing is art governed by science—practical execution (arte) must align with theoretical understanding (scientia).

records.briefDescription: The foresight and careful judgment required to anticipate and control engagements.
records.fullDescription: Prudentia or Providimento (Prudence/Foresight) enables practitioners to anticipate and control engagements. This intellectual virtue balances against audacia (audacity)—successful fencers need both courage to act and prudence to choose actions wisely. Prudence involves reading opponent intentions, anticipating likely actions, and making calculated tactical decisions rather than reckless gambles.
records.briefApplication: Exercise careful judgment and foresight in tactical decisions rather than reckless aggression.
records.fullApplication: Prudentia represents the intellectual virtue governing tactical decision-making. Rather than acting rashly or on pure instinct, prudent fencers carefully assess situations before committing to actions. Use prudence to evaluate opponent capabilities, identify likely attack patterns, recognize situations where defense is wiser than offense, and calculate risk versus reward for aggressive actions. Prudence doesn't mean timidity—it means taking calculated risks based on judgment rather than blind gambles. The balance between prudentia and audacia (audacity) creates effective fencing: too much prudence makes you passive and reactive; too much audacity makes you reckless and predictable. Develop prudence through experience and study: learn to recognize patterns that indicate opponent intentions, understand which situations favor attack versus defense, and know your own limitations. Prudent fencers survive longer and capitalize on opponent mistakes rather than creating their own through rash actions. Master prudentia to develop the judgment that separates expert fighters from merely aggressive ones.

records.briefDescription: The boldness and courage to act decisively when opportunities arise.
records.fullDescription: Audacia (Audacity/Courage) provides the boldness to act decisively when opportunities arise. This virtue balances against prudentia (prudence)—while prudence provides careful judgment, audacity provides the will to execute aggressive actions when appropriate. Successful fencers need both: prudence to identify good opportunities, audacity to exploit them decisively.
records.briefApplication: Act decisively and boldly when opportunities arise rather than hesitating from excessive caution.
records.fullApplication: Audacia represents the martial virtue of decisive action. While prudentia helps you identify good opportunities, audacia gives you the courage to exploit them. Use audacity when you've identified clear advantages—commit fully to attacks rather than half-heartedly probing. Hesitation often proves more dangerous than bold action because it allows opponents to recognize and counter your intentions. However, audacity must be balanced with prudence: blind aggression leads to disaster, but well-calculated aggressive action wins exchanges. Develop audacity through training that builds confidence in your techniques and judgment. When you trust your skills and tactical assessment, you can commit to actions without second-guessing. The balance between audacia and prudentia creates complete fencers: prudent enough to avoid foolish risks, audacious enough to capitalize on opportunities. Against overly cautious opponents, audacity pressures them into mistakes. Master audacia to develop the decisiveness that wins exchanges even when multiple options might technically work.

records.briefDescription: The perceptive judgment required to see opponent intentions and opportunities.
records.fullDescription: Bon Occhio (Good Eye) designates the judgment required to perceive opponent intentions and opportunities. Chapter 3 instructs: 'With your eye on the weapon that can attack you, seize both the tempo and the measure together.' The good eye represents perceptual awareness that reads opponents through visual cues, recognizes patterns indicating likely actions, and identifies the opportune moments for attack or defense.
records.briefApplication: Develop visual awareness to read opponent intentions and recognize tactical opportunities.
records.fullApplication: Bon Occhio represents the perceptual skill separating effective fighters from those who react blindly. Good eye allows you to read opponent body language and weapon position to anticipate their actions before full commitment, recognize patterns in their attack timing that you can exploit, identify moments when they're vulnerable to your attacks, and perceive measure and tempo relationships that create opportunities. Develop bon occhio through focused observation during practice: don't just perform techniques mechanically, but actively watch opponents for telegraphing and patterns. The instruction to keep 'your eye on the weapon that can attack you' means maintaining visual focus on threats rather than being distracted. However, effective visual awareness uses peripheral vision to track multiple elements—opponent weapon, their body positioning, distance, and available space. With experience, pattern recognition becomes unconscious—your eye automatically identifies situations you've seen before. Master bon occhio to develop the perceptual awareness that enables anticipation and timing rather than purely reactive response.

records.briefDescription: The inner courage and will that enables decisive action in combat.
records.fullDescription: Cuore or Cor (Heart/Courage) provides the will to act decisively. Combined with bon occhio (good eye) in Vadi's anatomical diagram as 'L'ochio col cor' (Eye with Heart), this pairing emphasizes that perception without will to act is insufficient. Courage enables you to execute techniques even under pressure, to commit to actions despite fear, and to maintain composure in dangerous situations.
records.briefApplication: Maintain courage and composure to execute techniques decisively even under pressure.
records.fullApplication: Cuore represents the psychological foundation enabling martial effectiveness. Technical skill and tactical knowledge mean nothing if you cannot execute under pressure. Courage allows you to commit to attacks despite uncertainty about outcomes, maintain composure when opponents pressure you aggressively, execute defenses calmly rather than panicking, and continue fighting even when tired or slightly wounded. The pairing with good eye in Vadi's diagram suggests courage must combine with perception: seeing opportunities means nothing without courage to exploit them, while blind courage without perception leads to reckless failure. Develop cuore through progressive exposure to pressure: start with controlled drilling, advance to competitive sparring, and push yourself beyond comfort zones. Courage grows through experience—each successful execution under pressure builds confidence for future situations. However, distinguish courage from recklessness: true courage involves acting despite fear when action is appropriate, not ignoring danger through foolishness. Master cuore to develop the psychological resilience that enables performing your best technique even in stressful combat.

records.briefDescription: The speed and quickness required for effective technique, described as 'quick like a greyhound.'
records.fullDescription: Prestezza and Presto (Speed/Quickness) describe the velocity required for effective technique. Vadi instructs practitioners to move 'quick like a greyhound' (levorero), emphasizing that proper timing requires appropriate speed. However, speed must be controlled and directed—Vadi's emphasis on compact movement suggests efficient quickness rather than wild haste. Speed applies to attacks, defenses, and guard transitions.
records.briefApplication: Develop controlled speed in all actions while maintaining technical precision.
records.fullApplication: Prestezza represents crucial speed that enables effective technique. Slow movements telegraph intentions, giving opponents time to defend or counter. Use appropriate speed for attacks—fast enough that opponents cannot easily react, but controlled enough to maintain accuracy and defensive coverage. Defensive actions particularly require speed, as you're responding to opponent initiatives with less preparation time. However, distinguish speed from haste: hasty movements become sloppy and lose effectiveness, while true speed maintains technical precision at high velocity. The greyhound metaphor emphasizes athletic quickness rather than frantic rushing. Develop prestezza through deliberate practice: master techniques slowly first to ensure correct form, then gradually increase speed while maintaining quality, and train specifically for explosive acceleration from static positions. Speed also has tactical dimensions—varying your tempo between quick and measured actions prevents opponents from timing you. Against slow opponents, your speed creates overwhelming advantage. Master prestezza to develop the athletic quickness that enables advanced technique.

records.briefDescription: The principle that the head is connected to the weighted foot through body alignment.
records.fullDescription: Weight connection describes how the head is 'connected' (atacata) to the weighted foot in Vadi's passeggiar stance. The advanced leg's knee bends while the rear leg extends, creating the distinctive posture where body weight aligns from head through the forward leg. This detailed explanation of biomechanics was unprecedented in fencing literature of the period, showing Vadi's systematic approach to understanding body mechanics.
records.briefApplication: Maintain proper body alignment with weight connected from head to lead foot through bent knee.
records.fullApplication: Weight connection represents Vadi's sophisticated understanding of biomechanics in his distinctive stance. When you execute passeggiar, your head should align over your lead foot through your bent front knee, creating a connected line of weight transfer. This alignment provides stability, power generation through proper structure, and efficient weight transfer for attacks and footwork. Use weight connection to optimize your techniques: when attacking, drive power from the rear leg through your aligned structure into your strike; when defending, maintain the connection to stay balanced and ready to counter. Poor alignment disconnects your structure, reducing power and stability. The concept shows Vadi's analytical approach—rather than just describing what stance looks like, he explains the biomechanical principle that makes it effective. Practice maintaining weight connection through all movements, not just static positions. Modern practitioners should study biomechanics to understand how this principle optimizes force generation and balance. Master weight connection to develop the efficient power transfer that characterizes proper passeggiar.

records.briefDescription: Rotational throws and body mechanics used in close combat.
records.fullDescription: Giramento (Turning/Rotation) indicates rotational throws and body mechanics in close combat. These turning techniques use rotational force to unbalance and throw opponents, leveraging circular motion rather than just linear force. Giramento appears in both wrestling contexts and in describing rotational body mechanics for generating power in strikes.
records.briefApplication: Use rotational body mechanics for both throws in close play and power generation in strikes.
records.fullApplication: Giramento represents rotational mechanics critical to both grappling and striking. In close play, use turning motions to unbalance and throw opponents—circular force is often more effective than trying to lift or push directly. Rotate your body while maintaining grips to create throwing force opponents cannot easily resist. The turning principle also applies to strikes: many powerful cuts rely on body rotation coordinated with arm movement. Don't just swing with your arms—rotate your torso and hips to add rotational power. The principle appears in Vadi's anatomical diagram with the Orso (Bear) representing turning function. Practice giramento in both contexts: drilling throws that use rotation, and cutting exercises that emphasize rotational body mechanics. The circular nature means you can redirect opponent force rather than opposing it directly—when they push or pull, turn to use their force against them. Master giramento to develop rotational mechanics that multiply your effective power in both striking and grappling.

records.briefDescription: Arm grips, weapon grips, and body locks used in close combat.
records.fullDescription: Presa or Prese (Grip/Grips/Holds) encompass arm grips, weapon grips, and body locks used in giocco stretto (close play). These grips control opponent movement, facilitate throws and locks, enable weapon disarms, and create leverage for joint manipulation. Proper gripping technique is essential for effective close combat.
records.briefApplication: Use proper grips to control opponent body and weapon in close combat situations.
records.fullApplication: Presa represents fundamental close combat control. Once at grappling range, proper grips determine who controls the engagement. Use weapon grips to control opponent swords—grabbing their blade, hilt, or crossguard prevents them from striking effectively while enabling your techniques. Body grips control opponent movement: arm controls restrict their striking and defend gripping options, while body locks immobilize for throws or strikes. Develop sensitivity in gripping—don't just grab and hold, but feel opponent resistance and intentions through contact. Strong grips combined with proper leverage defeat stronger opponents through technical advantage. However, establishing grips requires timing—attempting grips while opponents can counter freely is dangerous. Use sword actions to create opportunities: after parrying or crossing, grip their weapon before they recover; after striking, grip exposed limbs before they return to guard. The greyhound symbolism in Vadi's anatomical diagram emphasizes speed in gripping. Master presa to develop close combat control that enables throws, disarms, and strikes from grappling range.

records.briefDescription: Joint manipulation techniques and locks applied in close combat.
records.fullDescription: Ligadura (Joint Lock/Bind) describes joint manipulation techniques used in close combat. These locks control opponents through pain compliance or mechanical advantage, forcing them to comply with your actions or risk injury. Ligadura can target arms, wrists, fingers, or other joints, using leverage to overcome resistance.
records.briefApplication: Use joint locks to control opponents through mechanical advantage and pain compliance.
records.fullApplication: Ligadura represents sophisticated close combat technique that controls opponents through mechanical advantage over their joints. Rather than relying purely on strength, joint locks use proper leverage to make opponent positions biomechanically weak. Use arm locks after successful weapon disarms or when grappling, wrist locks when you've gripped opponent hands or weapon, and finger locks for fine control when you've established contact. The 'lock' terminology indicates positions where opponent joints cannot move without injury—you've locked them into compliance. However, establishing locks requires proper setup: attempting locks from poor positions or against prepared opponents fails. Use combinations: strike to create opportunity, grip to control, then apply lock. Joint locks can force disarms by attacking weapon-holding hands or create throws by controlling arms while unbalancing. Practice with care—locks can injure training partners if applied too forcefully. Master ligadura to develop sophisticated control that defeats opponents through technical manipulation rather than strength.

records.briefDescription: Takedowns and body-to-body throws in close combat.
records.fullDescription: Gettare (Throwing) encompasses takedowns and body-to-body throws used in giocco stretto. These techniques unbalance opponents and bring them to the ground where they're vulnerable to finishing strikes, pins, or submission. Effective throws combine proper grips, body positioning, and mechanical advantage to overcome opponent resistance.
records.briefApplication: Use throws to bring opponents to ground where they're vulnerable to finishing techniques.
records.fullApplication: Gettare represents finishing tactics in close combat—once you've successfully closed distance and established control, throws allow you to end exchanges decisively. Proper throws unbalance opponents so they cannot maintain footing, using mechanical advantage rather than just strength. Use throws after establishing good grips that control opponent balance, when you've unbalanced them through strikes or sword actions, or when you've created leverage advantage through positioning. Throws work through several principles: hip throws use your hip as fulcrum to lift and rotate opponents over; leg sweeps or trips remove supporting legs while upper body control maintains their fall direction; rotational throws use turning momentum to overwhelm their balance. Ground positions create extreme vulnerability in armed combat—the thrown fighter cannot use their weapon effectively while standing opponents can deliver finishing strikes. Practice throws with proper safety: controlled drilling with compliant partners before attempting against resistance. Master gettare to develop finishing capability that capitalizes on close combat success.

records.briefDescription: Arm breaks and joint destruction techniques.
records.fullDescription: Rompere (Breaking) includes arm breaks and joint destruction techniques, with plays promising: 'With my skill I will break your arm.' These represent extreme close combat techniques used when control or pain compliance is insufficient. Breaking techniques target joints or bones to physically disable opponent limbs, removing their ability to continue fighting.
records.briefApplication: Use breaking techniques in extreme circumstances when lesser control proves insufficient.
records.fullApplication: Rompere represents the most severe close combat techniques—actual joint or bone destruction rather than just control or pain compliance. Use breaking techniques only in serious combat when lesser methods have failed or when immediate, decisive action is required. Breaking techniques require committing fully: half-hearted attempts fail while alerting opponents to your intent. Targets include elbow joints hyperextended beyond breaking point, finger joints bent backward past tolerance, and wrist joints torqued to failure. The manuscript's explicit mention of breaking indicates this was expected in serious combat, not just theoretical. However, modern practitioners must never practice actual breaking—drilling these techniques requires extreme control and understanding that they're simulation only. Study the mechanics to understand leverage and vulnerability, but never test to actual breaking point. The severity of breaking techniques shows Vadi's manuscript addressed real combat where permanent injury was acceptable outcome. Master the theory of rompere while maintaining ethical training practices that preserve partner safety.

records.briefDescription: Techniques to strip opponents of their weapons.
records.fullDescription: Disarmare (To Disarm) and Torre l'Arme (To Take the Weapon) describe techniques to strip opponents of their weapons. These represent decisive tactical victories in armed combat—unarmed opponents face extreme disadvantage against armed fencers. Disarms typically combine weapon control through crossing or binding, joint manipulation or pain compliance to force weapon release, and physical wrenching to tear weapons from grips.
records.briefApplication: Use disarms to gain decisive tactical advantage by removing opponent weapons.
records.fullApplication: Disarmare represents one of the most decisive actions in armed combat. Successfully disarming creates overwhelming tactical advantage—you remain armed while opponents have lost their weapon. Use disarms after establishing strong weapon binds that prevent opponent recovery, when you've established grips that control their weapon hand, after striking to disorient or weaken their grip, or through joint locks that force compliance. Disarms require commitment—half-hearted attempts alert opponents without succeeding. Combine techniques: cross their weapon to control it, grip their hand or hilt, then wrench using body rotation while applying joint pressure. The crossguard and pommel serve as tools for disarming—hook their blade with your cross, trap their hands between sword components. Against serious opponents, disarms rarely succeed through single techniques—create situations where multiple factors (pain, distraction, leverage) combine to overwhelm their grip. Practice disarms extensively but recognize they're high-difficulty techniques requiring setup. Master disarmare to develop tactical options that end exchanges decisively when grappling.

records.briefDescription: Gripping the blade with the left hand for enhanced control and leverage.
records.fullDescription: Mezza Spada grip (Half-Sword Grip) positions the left hand on the blade for enhanced control and leverage in close quarters. This technique enables precise thrusts into armor gaps, powerful wrenching actions for control and disarms, and improved leverage for binding and pushing opponent weapons. The shortened lever arm provides fine control that full-length gripping cannot match.
records.briefApplication: Use half-sword grip for precision thrusts in armor and enhanced leverage in close combat.
records.fullApplication: Mezza Spada grip transforms your sword from a cutting tool into a precision thrusting and leveraging instrument. Grip the blade with your left hand to shorten effective length, creating a rigid spike for thrusting into small armor gaps—armpits, visors, joints. The two-point control (right hand on hilt, left on blade) provides fine directional control that single-hand gripping cannot match. Use half-sword grip primarily in armored combat where cutting is ineffective but precise thrusting finds gaps, or in close unarmored combat for enhanced binding and control. The grip also provides powerful wrenching leverage—controlling the blade middle gives mechanical advantage for redirecting opponent weapons or forcing disarms. However, the grip commits you to close distance—you cannot cut effectively with shortened grip, and retreating requires releasing the blade grip. The right side of the blade is typically held (false edge side), protecting your hand from your own edge. Practice half-sword to develop comfort with this seemingly unnatural grip that proves essential in certain tactical contexts.

records.briefDescription: Close-range impacts with the sword's pommel.
records.fullDescription: Colpi di Pomo (Pommel Strikes) deliver close-range impacts with the sword's pommel, particularly effective against armored opponents. The pommel becomes a mace-like striking tool at grappling distance, targeting the head, face, and other exposed areas. These strikes use sword weight and short-distance acceleration to deliver concussive force.
records.briefApplication: Use pommel strikes for close-range impacts when at grappling distance.
records.fullApplication: Colpi di Pomo transforms your sword's pommel into an impact weapon at close distance. When you've closed to grappling range, cutting becomes difficult or impossible, but the pommel can deliver powerful short-range strikes. Target opponent heads with hooking blows, faces with upward strikes, or bodies with hammering impacts. Pommel strikes work particularly well against armored opponents where cutting is ineffective—the blunt impact can cause concussion even through helmets. Use pommel strikes after establishing control through grips or bindings, when you've unbalanced opponents making them unable to defend, or opportunistically during grappling exchanges. The short distance required means pommel strikes occur within wrestling range, often combined with grappling techniques. Practice pommel strikes with proper safety—even training pommels can cause injury if struck with full force. The round pommel shape specified by Vadi 'to fit in the fist' provides good striking surface. Master colpi di pomo to develop complete close combat offense that includes striking options when cutting is impractical.

records.briefDescription: Counter-techniques and responses when plays fail or are countered.
records.fullDescription: Contrario (Counter) designates counter-techniques and responses when plays fail or are countered. Vadi's principle that 'every reverse finds his right, contrary by contrary without an end' suggests infinite counter and re-counter possibilities. These transitions between modes of play enable continuous adaptation as exchanges develop beyond initial techniques.
records.briefApplication: Prepare counter-responses for when your techniques are defended or fail to complete.
records.fullApplication: Contrario represents the principle that no technique is absolute—every action has potential counters, requiring prepared responses. When opponents counter your attacks, you must have ready follow-ups rather than simply failing. Develop contrario thinking: for each technique, identify likely opponent counters, and prepare your responses to those counters. This creates layered tactical awareness: your initial technique is actually a probe that forces opponent response, revealing their counter method, which you exploit with your prepared contrario. The 'contrary by contrary without an end' principle means exchanges can theoretically continue indefinitely as each counter is met with another counter. However, practical reality means most exchanges resolve within a few actions. Use contrario to develop fluid fighting that doesn't rely on single techniques working perfectly. If your thrust is parried, have a prepared counter-cut; if your cut is avoided, have a follow-up thrust. Master contrario to develop adaptable fighting that continues effectively even when initial techniques fail.

records.briefDescription: The primary cutting edge on the knuckle side of the sword.
records.fullDescription: Bon Filo or Filo Dritto (True Edge/Good Edge) designates the primary cutting edge on the knuckle side of the sword. This edge delivers most cutting attacks due to favorable biomechanics and edge alignment with natural striking motions. The 'true' or 'good' designation reflects its primacy over the false edge.
records.briefApplication: Use the true edge for maximum cutting effectiveness in most strikes.
records.fullApplication: Bon Filo represents your primary cutting tool, delivering most effective cuts due to biomechanical advantage and edge alignment. When you grip the sword naturally, this edge aligns with forehand striking motions, creating powerful, efficient cuts. Use true edge for all fendenti (descending cuts), for mandritto strikes generally, for finishing cuts requiring maximum power, and any time cutting effectiveness is paramount. The edge geometry and alignment mean true edge cuts generate more force with less effort than false edge equivalents. However, don't exclusively rely on true edge—tactical situations sometimes favor false edge strikes despite reduced power. The distinction between true and false edges structures Italian cutting vocabulary: mandritto typically uses true edge, roverso typically uses false edge. Maintain true edge through proper sword care—sharpen and align regularly. Practice cutting mechanics that optimize true edge impact: proper body rotation, correct edge alignment at impact, and follow-through that maintains edge-on contact. Master bon filo usage to develop powerful cutting offense.

records.briefDescription: The secondary cutting edge on the thumb side of the sword.
records.fullDescription: Filo Falso (False Edge) designates the secondary cutting edge on the thumb side of the sword. While less biomechanically optimal than the true edge for most cuts, the false edge enables certain techniques and strike angles impossible or awkward with the true edge. Roverso (backhand) strikes typically employ the false edge.
records.briefApplication: Use the false edge for backhand strikes and situations where true edge is impractical.
records.fullApplication: Filo Falso provides cutting capability from positions and angles where true edge cannot effectively reach. While generally less powerful than true edge cuts due to biomechanics, false edge strikes serve important tactical purposes: enabling backhand strikes without reversing sword position, allowing cuts during certain guard transitions, providing unexpected attack angles that surprise opponents, and facilitating specific techniques like falso dritto and falso roverso. Use false edge when your sword is positioned with true edge away from targets and reversing would take too long, when combinations flow naturally with false edge strikes, or when deceptive attack angles serve tactical purposes. Modern practitioners should not neglect false edge—while it may cut less powerfully, the tactical advantages often outweigh pure cutting force. Practice false edge mechanics: these cuts use different body rotation and muscle engagement than true edge equivalents. Master filo falso to develop complete cutting vocabulary that threatens from any sword position.

records.briefDescription: The crossguard extending the same length as the handle, used for hooking and trapping.
records.fullDescription: Elzo or Elso (Crossguard/Hilt) extends the same length as the handle plus pommel, described as 'strong and square' with 'wide and pointed end.' This ferro (iron/crossguard) serves multiple purposes: protecting the hands from sliding blades, providing hooking and trapping points for opponent weapons, and offering striking surfaces for close combat. Vadi specifies particular dimensions proportional to the handle and fighter size.
records.briefApplication: Use the crossguard for hand protection and as a tool for hooking opponent weapons.
records.fullApplication: Elzo serves critical functions beyond simple hand protection. The specified length (matching handle plus pommel) and pointed ends create effective tools for techniques: hook opponent blades with the cross arms during bindings and crossings, trap opponent hands or weapon components between cross and blade, strike with the cross ends at close distance, and block or deflect strikes using the cross as a barrier. The 'strong and square' description suggests robustness—the cross must withstand significant force during bindings and cannot bend or break under pressure. The proportional sizing to handle ensures balanced sword handling while providing adequate coverage. Use the cross actively in technique, not just as passive protection. During crossed positions, rotate your cross to hook under or over opponent blades for control. The cross also provides feedback during bindings—you can feel opponent pressure through contact with the cross. Modern practitioners should appreciate the cross as an integral technical tool, not just decorative guard. Master elzo usage to develop sophisticated binding and weapon control techniques.

records.briefDescription: The round counterweight and striking tool at the sword's end.
records.fullDescription: Pomo (Pommel) must be round 'in fist closed,' serving both as a counterweight and striking weapon. The pommel balances the blade weight, enabling proper handling characteristics and allowing one-handed technique when necessary. The round shape provides good striking surface for pommel strikes in close combat and ensures secure grip termination that won't snag or catch.
records.briefApplication: Use the pommel as a counterweight for handling and as a close-range striking tool.
records.fullApplication: Pomo serves dual functions essential to proper sword design and technique. As counterweight, the pommel balances blade weight, shifting the sword's center of balance closer to the hands for better control and reducing fatigue during extended use. The weight and position enable quick point recovery after cuts and proper leverage for binding pressure. As a striking tool, the pommel becomes a close-range weapon: deliver hooking strikes to opponent heads, hammering blows to faces or bodies, and short-range impacts when cutting is impractical. The specified round shape 'in fist closed' ensures secure grip—your hand wraps around the handle with the pommel preventing your grip from sliding off, while the round contour provides comfortable, secure termination. Use pommel strikes when at grappling distance or when you've established control but cannot cut effectively. The pommel also provides leverage for certain grips and manipulations. Modern practitioners should ensure pommels are properly secured—loose pommels compromise both handling and safety. Master pomo usage to develop complete sword control and close combat capabilities.

records.briefDescription: The square-shaped grip measuring one span long.
records.fullDescription: Manico (Handle/Grip) measures one span long and features a square shape for consistent hand placement. The square cross-section provides tactile feedback about edge orientation—you can feel blade alignment without looking. Proper handle length enables comfortable two-handed grip while maintaining proportional balance with the blade.
records.briefApplication: Use proper grip placement on the square handle for consistent edge alignment.
records.fullApplication: Manico design reflects Vadi's attention to functional detail. The specified one-span length provides enough grip space for both hands without excessive length that would compromise handling. The square cross-section proves particularly important: unlike round handles, square grips provide instant tactile feedback about edge orientation. In the chaos of combat, you can feel whether true or false edge faces your target without looking at your sword. This allows maintaining visual focus on opponents while ensuring proper edge alignment. Grip the handle with both hands for two-handed techniques, or with just the dominant hand when using extended guards or single-hand actions. The square shape also prevents the sword from rotating in your grip during impact—the flat surfaces lock against your palm and fingers. Modern practitioners should appreciate this design detail: period-appropriate square or diamond-section grips provide significant functional advantage over cylindrical modern reproductions. Proper hand placement on the handle affects all technique. Master manico usage by developing consistent, proper grip that maximizes control and edge awareness.
